Memorandum:- His Highness has asked me to enquire about the administration of estates of deceased persons who in their lifetime were foreign subjects but whose heirs are Bahrain subjects. His Highness considers that after the owner of the property is dead the estate is automatically owned by the heirs. If these heirs are Bahrain subjects His Highness considers that the Bahrain Courts should deal with the administration and division of the estate. 2. Such situations are likely to occur frequently because many of the offspring of foreignervS have A acquired Bahrain nationality by birth or in sbme cases by naturalisation. A case in question which occurred some years ago, was that of Sulman bin* Muttar, a large landowner and boat owner who at some time acquired British Indian nationality though he was born a Bahrain Arab. His sons and heirs were all Bahrain subjects. His estate however was dealt with by the Agency Court. 3- I should be interested to hear' your views on this matter. Adviser to the GovernmentNo. POLITICAL AGENCY, v BAHRAIN, 20th November, 1949. The Adviser to the Bahrain Government, Bahrain. Memorandum. Your memorandum No.l41-9A, dated the 7th November, 1949, regarding His Highness the Shaikh*s enquiry about the administration of estates of de ceased persons. 2t The law as it stands is laid down in Article 44 (5) of the Bahrain Order in Council which reads as follows: n hen a person subject to this Order dies in Bahrain or elsewhere intestate, then, until administration is granted, his property in Bahrain shall be vested in the Political Agent.*' i.e., jurisdiction over such property depends upon the nationality of the deceased not of the beneficiaries. I have consulted ar legal authority and can confirm that this is the universal practice in every country in the world. To make jurisdiction in this matter depend upon the nationality of the beneficiaries would clearly lead to administratively impossible situations when it is considered that under such an arrangement if, for example, a Bahrain subject died here aith a Turkish heir, the administration of the property would vest in the Turkish Courts. Doubtless you will explain this to His Highness.V-K A INDIA OFFICE RECORDS 'microfilm

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 29; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-12; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence relating to the estates of deceased persons in Bahrain. The papers are primarily letters from supplicants on matters of inheritance, custody, and the administration of estates, primarily property. The file also contains exchanges between the Political Agent and the Advisor to the Government of Bahrain, Charles Belgrave, on the claims of various supplicants.
